title: Everyone says that Google is the all seeing eye; do you believe that Google knows all? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, I don't believe that google knows all. You have control over it. I am traveling now by bus carrying my google logged in iphone. Google never knew where I am and where I was heading also. I had also taken precaution that google new less about my phone behavior. I had disable many features that I feel not comfortable to share with google. Back to google system. When you are first time onto the gmail signup process, you knowingly or unknowingly agree all the terms and condition of them. You missed the critical part where google store data and how can you retrive it and control it anytime. See the policy here. Google Terms of Service Google can see your activity once you are logged in to the gmail account. They know your visited website, location history if you share and may be all activities after you log in to gmail account. But if you want to control it, you can. Welcome to My Activity. They may even have your passwords saved on their browser chrome and also a credit card credentials if you once pay through it but trust them they have high encryption technology even they can't access. why they keep these much of information? Just for target and behavioral marketing. They target their add according to your preference and your search activity. They earn billions of dollar annually from these kind of effective marketing no has ever done in history. Be safe, control your account activity.

Google has a lot of data, but you have a lot of control over it. I don't allow Google to track my search history or my location history and I put up with the degraded experience on Google mobile maps as a result. There is no database or process at Google which could bring all of your data together in one place. Data is stored in service-specific databases with their own designs, addressing their own trade-offs. The way data is decrypted and accessed ensures that your data is only accessed for a specific (not vague or general) purpose, and almost always as a result of a request you made.
